quotes.quote: Scientific thought, then, is not momentary; it is not a static instance; it is a process.
Scientific theory is a contrived foothold in the chaos of living phenomena.
We are the recipients of scientific method. We can each be a creative and active part of it if we so desire.
Scientific research can reduce superstition by encouraging people to think and view things in terms of cause and effect.
For every scientific or engineering action, there is an equal and opposite social reaction.
Scientific truth is beyond loyalty and disloyalty.
A scientific approach means knowing what one knows and what one doesn't. Absolute or complete knowledge is unscientific.
A good scientific theory is one which is falsifiable, which has not been falsified.
Scientific principles and laws do not lie on the surface of nature. They are hidden, and must be wrested from nature by an active and elaborate technique of inquiry.
Theory is the essence of facts. Without theory scientific knowledge would be only worthy of the madhouse.
This means that to entrust to science - or to deliberate control according to scientific principles - more than scientific method can achieve may have deplorable effects.
Scientific research is one of the most exciting and rewarding of occupations.
Scientific progress consists in the development of new concepts.
Scientific inquiry shouldn't stop just because a reasonable explanation has apparently been found.
In scientific thinking are always present elements of poetry. Science and music requires a thought homogeneous.
The scientific imagination always restrains itself within the limits of probability.
Scientific reality is the modern human condition, and you can see that in the symbolic nature of my work.
Scientific beliefs are supported by evidence, and they get results. Myths and faiths are not and do not.
Scientific method is the way to truth, but it affords, even in principle, no unique definition of truth. Any so-called pragmatic definition of truth is doomed to failure equally.
Great scientific discoveries have been made by men seeking to verify quite erroneous theories about the nature of things.
Scientific knowledge advances haltingly and is stimulated by contention and doubt.
A new scientific truth does not triumph by convincing opponents and making them see the light, but rather because its opponents eventually die, and a new generation grows up that is familiar with it.
Scientific knowledge is in perpetual evolution; it finds itself changed from one day to the next.
The real purpose of the scientific method is to make sure nature hasn't misled you into thinking you know something you actually don't know.
Scientific management promised to replace rules of thumb with accurate measurements.
Scientific thought and its creation is the common and shared heritage of mankind.
Science is what scientists do, and there are as many scientific methods as there are individual scientists.
Scientific reasoning is a kind of dialogue between the possible and the actual, between what might be and what is in fact the case.
In scientific work, those who refuse to go beyond fact rarely get as far as fact.
The scientific mind does not so much provide the right answers as ask the right questions.
